Dialogue: ...Because they're afraid of the truth... and the truth is this. They're trying to steal your money. Yeah, I said steal. The county commissioners rejected the bid on the schoolhouse. Why? Dialogue: Why?

Dialogue: Hi, Willie.

Dialogue: I'm going to be on that same street corner tomorrow, Mr. Duffy.

Dialogue: My boy is out distributing those handbills now.

Dialogue: I'll have some orange pop if you don't mind.

Dialogue: That's my pa.

Dialogue: Now we'll talk.

Dialogue: You've been talking for a long time, Mr. Stark.

Dialogue: You sleepy, Pappy? You want to have a nap?

Dialogue: He's a strong boy. Don't worry about him. He can take care of himself.

Dialogue: How old is the boy?

Dialogue: He was a neighbor's boy. They were poor folks. Both died. I couldn't have any children, so... He's a good boy.

Dialogue: Oh, he's the best. I couldn't love him any more if he was my own flesh and blood.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: And now you, Mrs. Stark?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Oh, there isn't very much to tell about me.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How did you meet?

Dialogue: I was teaching school and one day a pupil walked in. It was Willie. I couldn't have a grown man in the class and Willie wanted to learn so badly... so I married him.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Is that the only reason?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Except that I loved him.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Get the coffee, Lucy.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: When did they fire you, Mrs. Stark?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: A couple of weeks ago. I'd been teaching for a long time and nobody ever said I wasn't all right. But I don't care. Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'm going to run. They can't keep me from running.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If you don't mind the truth, Mr. Stark, you haven't much of a chance.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'm going to run. They're not going to kick me around like I was dirt.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I don't care if Willie loses... just so he gets the truth to the people. Isn't that true, Willie?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Isn't it, Willie?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Hmmm?... Yeah, yeah, sure, that's right.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Well, if you lose you can give a little more time to studying your law books.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Oh, you studying law too?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: By myself, at night.

Speaker: pappy
Dialogue: Willie's a smart boy.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: If I ever find the time I'm going to take a course at the university.

Dialogue: What happened, Tommy boy? What's the matter?

Dialogue: I gave out the handbills, Pa.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Speak up. Speak up.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Let him tell it his own way. Go on, Tommy.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: This time they were waiting for me. They took them away from me. Threw them in the dirt and beat me up. I brought some of them back.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Good boy. Have you eaten yet, Tom?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Let him wash up first.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'm going to run... and you're not going to stop me. I'm gonna run even if I don't get a single vote.

Dialogue: Here you are... the last of the Willie Stark articles. Now can I go?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Yes. You've earned your vacation. You've been writing these like you really mean them.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: jack

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Hello, Mother.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You look beautiful, Mother.

Speaker: mcevoy
Dialogue: Can't that wait until this evening?

Dialogue: How long do you plan on staying?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Two or three weeks. If that's all right with you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Stepfather, Mother.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yes, Mother.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Excuse me... I...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Dr. Stanton, I presume.

Dialogue: Is my shingle showing?

Dialogue: Good to see you, boy. Very good.

Dialogue: Good to see you, Judge. How have you been? What have you been doing?

Dialogue: Oh, just sitting here... waiting for all of you to come home. You know, when a man starts to get old his eyes stray and play funny tricks on him. Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Do you mind if I kiss your niece, sir?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Thank you, Mother. Thank you very much.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: We were just discussing whether you should...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I like what I'm doing, Mother.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: A lot of people like them.

Dialogue: A lot of people are fools. Articles like that shouldn't be permitted. They only tend to incite people.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What are you afraid of?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: I thought they were very good. I was proud of you, Jack. I was particularly interested in Stark's ideas on health and medicine. You know the conditions at the hospital I work in. They're intolerable. I'd like to meet this Willie Stark. He sounds like an honest man.

Dialogue: Honest man? This state is full of these log-cabin Abe Lincolns with price tags on them. The louder he yells the higher his price.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You think you can buy anything, don't you?

Speaker: mcevoy
Dialogue: Yes, don't you?

Dialogue: What do you think, Judge?

Dialogue: I think this state could stand a few changes.

Dialogue: Well, I'll tell you what I think --

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Oh, please... let's not talk politics.

Dialogue: To the young people... to Anne, to Jack, to Adam... To what lies before them. To the world they'll make... in spite of the mistakes we've made.

Dialogue: You? You can be bought too. As a matter of fact you have been. And with my money.

Speaker: mcevoy
Dialogue: Your mother wouldn't approve.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Apologize? I'd rather die.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well, I don't. Neither do you. You don't love him, Mother. You never did.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I can get along without him. You need this house. And the parties. And the cars and the clothes and the lies. I don't. It's the truth, Mother, face it. For once in your life, face it.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Anne, Burden's Landing is a place on the moon. It isn't real. It doesn't exist. It's me pretending I live on what I earn. Dialogue: And do what?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: And live in a shack and eat red beans. Anne, what do you want me to do?

Dialogue: Oh, Jack, Jack, you haven't been sure. You've gone from one thing to the other... a year at law school, and now this job as a reporter...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Are you afraid I can't make a living?

Dialogue: Oh, no, Jack, it isn't that. I don't care about the money. It... it's just that I... I want you to be something.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What is it you want me to be?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I don't know. It's just that I want you to be... to do... something important.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Like your father. All right. I'll run for governor.  Anne, I'm sorry. I'm sorry I said that.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: All right, Jack. I'll go away with you. I'll do anything you want me to do.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Anne, I've wanted you to say that more than anything in the world, and now that you've said it... Anne, I guess you were right. I'm not sure of anything, including myself. I'm not sure I could live up to the...  Anne, wait for me. Please wait for me.

Dialogue: I'll wait for you.

Dialogue: Yeah.

Dialogue: A breach...

Dialogue: Of an agreement...

Dialogue: Stay there with him.

Dialogue: Why don't you give me a cigarette?

Dialogue: Yeah.

Dialogue: I don't know, Sadie. I really don't know.

Dialogue: Fine, Willie, fine.

Dialogue: Thanks.

Dialogue: No, Willie, no.

Dialogue: What I need is some sleep. Shut up!

Dialogue: Listen, Willie, try it on your feet this time.

Dialogue: Oh, no. Wait a minute. My feet are killing me. Let me stay here, huh?

Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: A man don't have to be governor.

Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: A great governor.

Dialogue: Since you won't let me sleep you might at least give me a drink.

Dialogue: So you told him.

Dialogue: Who told you?

Dialogue: That you're not going to be governor.

Dialogue: Jack! Told me what?... Told me what?

Dialogue: All right! That you've been framed, you poor sap.

Dialogue: Framed?

Dialogue: Is it true?

Dialogue: He wants to know if it's true.

Dialogue: Is it true?

Dialogue: That's what they tell me.

Dialogue: Here.

Dialogue: He's not used to a lot of things. Are you, Willie?

Dialogue: Why don't you lay off of him, Sadie?

Dialogue: Are you, Willie? Are you? Are you... are you, are you, are you?

Dialogue: Hi.

Dialogue: Well, things seem to have quieted down.

Dialogue: Yeah, I quieted him down.

Dialogue: He talks like she's his mammy... she's going to blow his nose for him.

Dialogue: Well, I'll take him from here on in. They're waiting for him at the barbecue.

Dialogue: Yeah, well give me a receipt for the body and I'll be on my way.

Dialogue: Hey, Willie, Willie... come on, wake up, Willie. Come on, Willie.

Dialogue: Where is he?

Dialogue: There he is.

Dialogue: Whoops!

Dialogue: Never touches the stuff. Lucy doesn't favor drinkin'.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: How'd you get him here? He was out stiff.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Hair of the dog that bit him.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Hair? He must have swallowed the dog.

Speaker: chairman
Dialogue: Ladies and gentlemen, it gives me a great deal of pleasure to introduce to you that true man of the people, the next governor of the state... Willie Stark.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: My friends...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: My friends... I...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I have a speech here. It's a speech about what this state needs. There's no need in my telling you what this state needs. You are the state and you know what you need... You over there... look at your pants. Have they got holes in the knees? Listen to your stomach. Did you ever hear it rumble from hunger?... And you, what about your crops? Did they ever rot in the field because the road was so bad you couldn't get them to market?... And you. What about your kids? Are they growing up ignorant as dirt, ignorant as you, 'cause there's no school for them?... No, I'm not going to read you any speech.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: But I am going to tell you a story. It's a funny story...

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: willie's voice
Dialogue: ...So get ready to laugh.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: What's he up to?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Shut up!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Get ready to bust your sides laughing, 'cause it's sure a funny story. It's about a hick... a hick like you, if you please. Yeah, like you. He grew up on the dirt roads and gully washes of a farm. He knew what it was to get up before dawn and get feed and slop and milk before breakfast... and then set out before sunup and walk six miles to a one-room, slab- sided schoolhouse. Oh, this hick knew what it was to be a hick, all right. He figured if he was going to get anything done, he had to do it himself. So he sat up nights and studied books. He studied law because he thought he might be able to change things some... for himself, and for folks like him.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: No, I'm not going to lie to you. He didn't start off thinking about the hicks and all the wonderful things he was going to do for them. No. No, he started off thinking of number one. But something came to him on the way. How he could do nothing for himself without the help of the people. That's what came to him. And it also came to him, with the powerful force of God's own lightning, back in his home country, when a schoolhouse collapsed because it was built of politics... rotten brick. It killed and mangled a dozen kids. But you know that story. The people were his friends because he fought that rotten brick. And some of the politicians down in the city, they knew that... So they rode up to his house in a big, fine, shiny car and said as how they wanted him to run for governor...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Sadie, he's wonderful... wonderful...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: ...So they told the hick... and he swallowed it. He looked in his heart and he thought in all humility how he'd like to try and change things. He was just a country boy who thought that even the plainest, poorest man can be governor if his fellow citizens find he's got the stuff for the job. Well, those fellows in the striped pants... they saw the hick and they took him in.

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Willie, what are you trying to do?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: There he is! There's your Judas Iscariot.  Look at him... lickspittle... nose- wiper.

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Play! Play!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Look at him!

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Play anything.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Look at him! Joe Harrison's dummy! Look at him!

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: That's a lie!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Look at him!

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Go get him, boys... go get him.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Now, shut up! Shut up, all of you. Now, listen to me, you hicks. Yeah, you're hicks too, and they fooled you a thousand times, just like they fooled me. But this time I'm going to fool somebody. I'm going to stay in this race. I'm on my own and I'm out for blood.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Listen to me, you hicks...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Listen to me and lift up your eyes and look at God's blessed and unflyblown truth... And this is the truth. You're a hick. And nobody ever helped a hick but a hick himself.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: All right, listen to me... listen to me. I was the hick they were going to use to split the hick vote. But I'm standing right here now on my hind legs... even a dog can learn to do that. Are you standing on your hind legs? Have you learned to do that much yet? Here it is, here it is, you hicks. Nail up anybody who stands in your way! Nail up Joe Harrison! Nail up McMurphy! And if they don't deliver, give me a hammer and I'll do it myself.

Speaker: politician
Dialogue: I want his throat cut, from ear to ear.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: No use going any further, Jack. We aren't printing them any more.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I thought the Chronicle line was --

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Divide and conquer? Stark is getting too big for his britches and the hicks are getting too smart. We're now supporting Harrison.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How do you square that?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I work here.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well, I don't... not any more.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Jack, you fool.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If you had any guts you'd print this...

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I work here. I take orders.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I know. You've got a wife and three kids and your boy goes to Princeton.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: You won't find it easy to get another job.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'm too rich to work.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We didn't do so good.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Double bourbon.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Same for me.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: And a beer.  I hear you got fired from the paper.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You heard wrong, Willie. I quit.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You're smart. 'Cause before I'm through with that mob they're not going to have enough money left to pay the boy that cleans the spittoons.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How do you feel, Willie?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I feel fine, fine. You see, Jack, I learned something.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yeah... what?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How to win.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I didn't see Willie again until his second campaign... four years later.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I drifted from job to job...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: ...That is, whenever I could find one.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: But always further and further away from Anne, and the life at Burden's Landing.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: But Willie wasn't drifting. He knew where he was going.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He had his foot in the door and he kept right on pushing to get in. He had lost the election but he had won the state... and he knew it... and the people knew it.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: They were all hopping on his bandwagon... even Tiny Duffy.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yep, Willie came back like he said he would.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Do you want to know what my platform is? Here it is: I'm going to soak the fat boys and I'm going to spread it thin.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Willie was right -- he'd learned how to win...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He spent a lot of money doing it... an awful lot of money... I was beginning to wonder where he got it from.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: There were rumors throughout the state that Willie was making deals with all kinds of people... strange deals... for Willie Stark.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: The second time out, it wasn't a campaign... it was a slaughter. It was Saturday night in a mining town.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He came back and he took me with him.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: This is Jack Burden, a friend of mine. From now on he's going to live here. Give him anything he wants.

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Let these boys through, officer.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Duffy works for me now.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: It looks like everybody works for you.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: No. No, not yet. But I want to keep him around. He reminds me of something I never want to forget.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Come on, come on, come on, come on. Are these the boys?

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: These are the boys that can get the boys.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How many do you think we can get?

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Fifty.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Five dollars a head.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What do you think, Sugar? Do they look like good boys?

Speaker: sugar boy
Dialogue: T-t-they b-b-better be.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Get a hundred... All right, go on, all of you. Blow. Blow, blow. You too, Duffy. Go on.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Handbill distributors.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If they all look like them I'd hate not to take one.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: That's the object. Not like when they beat up my boy Tom.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How is Tom?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh, he's fine. He starts college in the fall.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Oh. And Lucy?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Fine... fine.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Hey, I need a boy... Where's a boy?  Listen, baby, you've got to double- space all of this... he can't read, see.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Sadie!

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Hi, Jack. How are you?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Sadie is my secretary now.  Oh, pardon me.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Fix your tie, Willie.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Hey, Sugar.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Keep everybody out of here. I want to talk to Jack and Sadie alone.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: From now on you're working for me.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Doing what?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I don't know. Something will turn up, won't it, Sadie?

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Yeah. We need a college man around... for research.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How much did they pay you on that newspaper?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Three hundred dollars a month.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I could buy you cheap, couldn't I?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: For a bag of salt.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: No. No, I don't play that way. I like you, boy. I always have. I'll tell you what I'll do. I'll give you four hundred dollars a month and traveling expenses.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You throw money around like it was money.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Money?... I don't need money. People give me things.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Because they believe in me.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I was going home again. But this time it was different. Now I had a feeling that maybe the waiting was over... for me, and for Anne.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's a far cry from where I come from... to this house.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: And standing here under the portrait of one of the greatest governors of this state, talking to you people... well, it's an honor I never thought I'd have.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Are there any questions?  Mr. McEvoy.

Speaker: mcevoy
Dialogue: No, I have no questions.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Judge?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: A few... but it will hold.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: I have a question.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Shoot.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: A lot of people in this state have been saying that you've been making deals... some of them with the very groups that you claim you're against. Is that true?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Adam, you know how rumors start...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Yes. Yes, that's true. I have nothing to hide. I'll make a deal with the devil if it'll help me carry out my program. But believe me, there are no strings attached to those deals.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: You're sure about that?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Doc, Jack here has been telling me how you feel about things... how you'd like to see a new hospital built, a hospital that's the biggest and best that money can buy. You want those things, Doc, because, well, because you're a man who wants to do good. Now, I'd like to ask you a question.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Shoot.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Do you know what good comes out of?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: You tell me, Mr. Stark.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Out of bad... that's what good comes out of. Because you can't make it out of anything else. You didn't know that, did you?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: No, I didn't... There's another question I'd like to ask you. You say there's only bad to start with and the good must come with the bad. Who's to determine what's good and what's bad?... You?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Why, that's easy. Just... just make it up as you go along.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Folks, there's a time to talk and there's a time to act. I think the time to act is right now. And with your support, I not only will win but I will do all of the things I promised. I need your help. Oh, I need it badly. But I'm not going to beg for it. In the name of this state which we love... in the name of the governor in whose house we meet... I demand it.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Well, what do you say, sir?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You've got to say yes. With you in the race...

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I'm an old bird... I...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: But a game one.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Look, I'll give you complete power as attorney general. You can do anything you see fit. I'll swing the ax to clear the way for you. Is that a deal?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: It's a deal.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Jack, we have to get back to town... a lot to do.  Dr. Stanton.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I'm very glad to have met you.

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: We want Willie! We want Willie!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: This is not a time for speechmaking. I should get on my knees and ask God to give me strength to carry out your will.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: This much I swear to you. These things you shall have. I'm going to build a hospital. The biggest that money can buy... and it will belong to you. That any man, woman, or child who is sick or in pain can go through those doors and know that everything will be done for them that man can do. To heal sickness. To ease pain. Free. Not as a charity, but as a right. And it is your right that every child shall have a complete education. That any man who produces anything can take it to market without paying toll. And no poor man's land or farm can be taxed or taken away from him. And it is the right of the people that they will not be deprived of hope...

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Does he mean it, Jack? Does he?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: That's his bribe.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What if it was his bribe! He swept the old gang out of office. What if they hollered like stuck pigs? He jammed through bill after bill and the people got what they wanted.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I demand that this bill be passed. Nobody's going to tell me how to run this state.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He started to build the roads, the schools, the power dams, to change the face of the state from one end to the other... His methods?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Politics is a dirty game... and he played it rough and dirty. Willie's little black book was a record of sin and corruption. And me, Jack Burden? I kept the book and added up the accounts.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Clown, show-off, playboy, they yelled at him. Building football stadiums. Fiercely proud of his son who played in them.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh, look at him go. He's going to be All-American.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: They said he was building up a private army. But he was building, always building...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Always playing up to the crowd. Letting them trample on tradition. Well, tradition needed trampling on.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: The crowd loved it... Willie loved it... and so did I.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: You low-down, no-good redneck...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What goes on here?

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: That's what Sadie wants to know.  The boss poses for too many pictures.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: I'll kill him.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Why, Sadie, I'm surprised at you.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: I'll kill him.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: I hate all women.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Was she pretty?

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Was she pretty?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If I met her on the street I'd never recognize her.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Was she pretty?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How should I know? I wasn't looking at her face... Look, if it's going to cause all this grief, why don't you let him go?

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Let him go? I'll kill him. I'll drive him out of this state.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Just because a guy's sitting with a couple of girls on his knees in public...

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Public or private... I know him. How about what happened in Chicago? That girl on skates... and the time you both went to St. Louis... There's a new invention, you know, Photography and newsreels. Willie Stark in a nightclub... Willie Stark with a blonde.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You could always bleach your hair.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: I could also break every bone in his neck. After all I've done for him... Now he goes two-timing me.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He's been two-timing Lucy. So there's another kind of arithmetic for what he's doing to you.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Lucy?  If she had her way he'd be back in Kanoma City slopping the hogs right now. And he knows it. He knows what she'd do for him. She had her chance.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You seem to think Lucy's on her way out, don't you?

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: He'll ditch her... Give him time.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You ought to know.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Hey, you got the wrong guy. I'm not the hero of this piece.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: All right, come on, both of you. Let's go, hurry it up.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Come on. Pillsbury put his hand in the pork barrel and got caught. You know, I never did trust that guy.

Speaker: newsmen
Dialogue: Have you heard about Pillsbury? What do you intend to do about Pillsbury? How about it, Governor?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Later, boys, later.  Say, Jack, go back and get the Judge. Let's get him over to my hotel just as soon as you can.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: You promised we could... uh... discuss my charity project... Children's home?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Well, I'm very sorry. Something very important came up. You'll call me later, won't you?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Yes, certainly.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: We're late.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Look at you, Pillsbury. Fifty years old, gut-sprung, teeth gone, never had a dime. If the Almighty had intended for you to be rich he'd have taken care of that a long time ago. The idea of you being rich... that's plain blasphemy. Ain't that a fact?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Answer me!

Speaker: pillsbury
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Louder, man. Don't mumble. Speak up. Say it's a fact, a blasphemous fact.

Speaker: pillsbury
Dialogue: It's a fact, a blasphemous fact.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Yeah?... Oh, I see.  Dumond can't come. He says his wife is sick.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I don't care if she's dying. Sugar, get the car. Get him and bring him over here.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Now, you know what you're supposed to do, don't you, Pillsbury? You're supposed to stay poor and take orders. Oh, there'll be some sweetening for you from time to time... but Duffy'll take care of that. Don't you go setting yourself up on your own again, do you understand that?

Speaker: pillsbury
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Louder, man. And say, I understand that.

Speaker: pillsbury
Dialogue: I understand that.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Give him a pen and some paper, Sadie.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: See who that is, Duffy.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh, hello, Judge. Sit down. I'll be with you in just a couple of seconds.  Did you sign it?

Speaker: pillsbury
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Well, sign it! Don't put any date on it. I can fill that in when I need it.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Now bring it to me.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Now get out.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: The papers have the story.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Yeah, I know.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: They're talking about impeachment proceedings.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Against who?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: This time, Pillsbury.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I got that "this time," Judge.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: How true is it?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's too true.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Yes?  This is it, Willie. Jeff Hopkins on the wire.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What have we got on Hopkins, Jack?  All right, Tiny'll talk to you in the morning.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Get going, Tiny.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: You haven't answered my question. Why are you saving Pillsbury's hide?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'm not a bit interested in Pillsbury's hide. It's something much more important than that. If the McMurphy boys get the notion they can get away with this, there's no telling where they'll stop.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Or where you will... Pillsbury is guilty. As attorney general of this state, it's my job to prosecute.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Judge, you talk like Pillsbury was... was human. He isn't. He's a thing. You don't prosecute an adding machine if the spring goes busted and makes a mistake. You fix it. Well, I fixed him. I'm not a bit interested in Pillsbury. It's something much bigger than that.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Yes, it is.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He's right, Judge. Can't you see that he's right?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: He's right because you want him to be right. Because you're afraid to admit you've made a mistake. Do it now before it's too late.  I'm offering my resignation as attorney general. You'll have it in writing by messenger in the morning... dated.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It took you a long time to make up your mind, Judge. A long time. What made you take such a long time?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I wasn't sure.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: And now you are?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'll tell you what you are. You're scared. You sat in that big easy chair of yours for thirty years and played at being a judge. Then all of a sudden I came along and put a bat in your hand, and I said, go ahead, Judge, start swinging. And you did. And you had a wonderful time. But now you're scared. You don't want to get your hands dirty. You want to pick up the marbles... but you don't want to get your hands dirty. Look at my whole program, Judge. How do you think I put that across?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I knew how, but I never knew why.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You're not by any chance thinking of going over to McMurphy's boys, are you?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I'm through with politics.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'm happy to hear that.  No hard feelings.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Are you coming with me, Jack?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: You're making a mistake.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Do you think he means it when he says he's through with politics, Sadie?

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: No. No, I don't.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What about you, Jack?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I've known the Judge all my life. He's always meant everything he's said.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: All right. All right. Take it easy. I'll take your word for it.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Sugar, take Miss Stanton home.  When am I going to see you again?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What's the matter, Anne?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Please take me home now, Sugar Boy.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You've got to understand me.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I understand you. It's myself I don't understand.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Do you think I like sneaking around corners any more than you do? But right now, with the Pillsbury business and with your uncle quitting... If I got a divorce...

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Maybe we'd better stop seeing each other.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: No. No, we won't stop seeing each other, will we?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Because you believe in what I tell you.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Because I believe what you tell me.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Good evening, Governor Stark.  He gave the story to every paper in town.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Sugar, meet me at the hotel as soon as you can.

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: These are serious charges that Judge Stanton has given to the press. This legislature is entitled to a complete and full report on the Pillsbury affair. Let the truth be known.

Speaker: chairman
Dialogue: All those in favor, say aye... Motion carried. The house is adjourned.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: If you let Willie Stark get away with the Pillsbury graft, there's no telling...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: But we beat the Pillsbury rap... It's over.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: These things are never over. I'll tell you what I want you to do, Jack. I want you to start a new page in that black book of yours... under then name of Judge Stanton.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You're crazy. There's nothing on the Judge.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Why? Because his name is Stanton?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Ssshhh, easy.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What if I won't do it?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You know, some of this has rubbed off on you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What are you going to do? Have me shot?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: No... no... but I'll have to get myself a new boy.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I tell you there's nothing on the Judge.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Jack, there's something on everybody. Man is conceived in sin and born in corruption.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: It's a waste of time.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What's the matter, Jack? Are you afraid you might find something out?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I kept saying to myself that Willie was wrong about the Judge. If there was anything left at Burden's Landing, it was honor. I had to believe that.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Anne, I want to ask you a question. Was the Judge ever broke? Really broke?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Why do you want to know?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I don't want to know, but I've got to.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Did he tell you --

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Did who tell me?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I don't know. I... how should I know if the Judge was ever broke?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Hello... Come on, Anne, take this food and start cooking. I'm hungry.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Me, I'm on the thirsty side. Bring some glasses, Anne, quick.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: It's been a long time since I played this thing. What do you say we wake up the ghosts, huh?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Another glass, Anne, for a ghost.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Remember the last time I played this? You and Anne were dancing?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Shall we dance?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Let's... let's have a drink first.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No, no... keep playing. Anne and I want to hear this, don't we, Anne?  Adam... ghost... and me.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: What shall we drink to?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: To the ghost?... To Adam, to the director of the new medical center.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Don't you ever stop working for him?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Adam!

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: I came up here to get away...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Adam.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Well, I'm not. What's wrong with being the director of the new medical center?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Nothing, except that I'm not going to take it.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Why? Because your uncle resigned?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: That's partly it. There are other things.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: What other things?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: You too?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Yes, me too.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Anne, if Adam doesn't want to discuss it, let's not.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: All right, let's discuss it.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: But calmly.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Calmly. Go ahead, Jack. Why do you think he wants me?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Because you're the best man for the job.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: It could have nothing to do with my name being Stanton?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: It could have. Let's grant that.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: That's your answer.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No, it's not. If that were the only answer I wouldn't be with him any more. There's another side of it. I've learned something from him. You can't make an omelet without cracking eggs.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Or heads.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: But at least a hospital will be built, and the sick will be cared for.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: At what price?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: At any price.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Do you really believe that, Jack?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I really believe that Stark wants to do good. You do too. It's a matter of method. Many times out of evil comes good. Well, pain is an evil. As a doctor you should know that.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Pain is an evil; it is not evil. It is not evil in itself. Stark is evil.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: The people of the state don't think so.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: How would they know? The first thing he did was to take over the newspapers and the radio stations. Why be so afraid of criticism? If Stark is interested in doing good, he should also be interested in the truth. I don't see how you can separate the two. No, Stark is not for me.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: No, Stark is not for you. Well, what is for you? Pride. Pride, that's all it is... foolish, stupid pride. All you've ever talked about is what you could do if... if somebody would tear down and build. All right, all right, somebody has, and he's given it to you. But he's not for you. No, he's not for you.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Anne... Anne...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Will I find anything, Judge? Will I? I didn't find it all at once. It takes a long time to go through old courthouse records and musty deeds... a very long time. But it wasn't too hard for me. I was well trained in research, especially this kind.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I found what I didn't want to find.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Have some photostat copies made of these. I'll be back tomorrow for them.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: sadie's voice
Dialogue: It's me, Sadie Burke.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Wait a minute.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: All right, come in.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Phew! Awful lot of smoke. Awful lot of whisky. You sober?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Stone.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: I'll have one with you.  What are you hiding out for?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'm not. I've been sleeping.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: For four days? You've been back in town for four days.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Willie knows everything.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Willie's worried about his boy.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Willie's boy is worried about Willie's boy.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Well, why don't you put something on the phonograph -- a low-down, mean blues. Play it over and over again until you're sick of it. Then crack it and go back to work.  I do it all the time.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: That's not my problem.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: No, it isn't your problem.  I'll wait for you if you want to powder your nose.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'll be with you in a minute.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Hmmm. Yeah, I can see it. I've got to look in the mirror to be able to see it. Soft, white skin... not like mine.  I had smallpox when I was a kid. Where I lived it seemed nearly all the kids had smallpox...

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: It leaves your face hard. Then she's got poise. Look at the way she holds her head... at just the right angle. That takes training. That takes years of training...

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: I see what Willie sees. Willie's got big ideas, Jack.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: A girl like that could be a governor's wife. Or even a President's.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: He ditched Lucy, he ditched me, and he'll ditch you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Answer me!

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: He'll ditch everybody in the whole world because that's what Willie wants. Nobody in the world but him.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: You and your high-tone friends. What do they know? What do they know about anything? Why did you have to mix her in?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You're crazy, Sadie. You're out of your mind.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Am I? Well, why don't you go down and ask her. Or ask him. Ask Willie.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Shut up!

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Go ahead, ask him.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Shut up!

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Ask him!

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Ow-oo... oh... oh.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He's off today.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's only practice. He'll be all right tomorrow... You been gone a long time, Jack.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yeah. I figured if you needed me you'd yell.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Why'd you lay around the hotel?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Thinking.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Things.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What did you find on the Judge?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You sure you didn't find anything on the Judge?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yeah, I'm sure.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You're going to keep trying, aren't you?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If you want me to.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I want you to. There's something else I want you to do too.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What? Bucket boy? Towel slinger? What?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What's eating you, Jack?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What else do you want me to do?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: If you've got something on your mind, boy, spit it out. We've been together too long to play games.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What do you want me to do?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I hear your pal Adam Stanton turned down the job as director of the hospital. That's bad. Especially at a time like this.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Oh? How did you hear it?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Why? What difference does it make?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I just wanted to know.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I heard it around.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How did you hear he turned it down, Willie?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'll be right back, Jack. I want to see what's happening here.

Speaker: coach
Dialogue: You going to practice the way I tell you.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'm going to do it the way I want to do it.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Tom, come here. What's going on here?

Speaker: coach
Dialogue: I don't care if he is your son, Governor... No special rules for him.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: It doesn't make any difference to me either way... whether I play or not.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Well, it does to me.  What do you want him to do?

Speaker: coach
Dialogue: To behave himself. Like the rest of the boys. Four times this season he's broken training. He comes on the practice field half potted.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Tom, you're going to have to obey the rules. Do you hear me? You're going to obey the rules.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I put 'em across, don't I? Every Saturday I put 'em across and I can still do it, drunk or sober. That's all you want, isn't it... for me to put 'em across so you can big-shot it around? Isn't that all you want?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Tom!  Tom, come here. Tom!

Speaker: helene
Dialogue: Come on, Tommy... let's go faster. Come on...

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Willie, Mr. Hale's here to see you.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Go on upstairs, Lucy. I have some business I want to talk over with Mr. Hale.

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: What I've got to say anybody can listen to... Where's your boy?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Now... now, don't get excited.  Get me another drink, Sugar.

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: My daughter may die.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: She's not going to die. She'll get the best medical attention there is. No expense will be spared.

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: Where's your boy?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I'll get him.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Wait a minute, Lucy. He's asleep. And the doctor said after a good night's sleep he'll be all right.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: No, he won't be all right unless you make him all right. I'll get him.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Lucy!  You care for a drink?

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: No thanks.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Accidents will happen, you know.

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: Accidents? Your boy was drunk.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I saw the police report. There... there was nothing about drunkenness on the police report.

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: Whose police and whose report? I say the boy was drunk. And I know it.

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: Right here before your father... I want you --

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Mr. Hale --

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Tom, the doctor says you need rest, boy.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I don't want you to try to cover up for me. I was wrong... that's all there is to it.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You don't know what you're talking about. I saw the police report --

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I don't care what the police report says. I was driving and I was drunk. It's all my fault.  Anything you want to do to me, you can do. Whatever you want me to do, I'll do.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Nobody has to do anything. Stop worrying. I'll take care of everything.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I don't want you to take care of anything.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Tom, go on upstairs and get some rest, boy. Go on... go on... go on.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Sugar, help him... Mr. Hale, come on over and sit down. You sure you wouldn't care for a drink, Mr. Hale?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Hey, Tiny, go home. Go on, out of here... out of here. Go on.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What business did you say you were in?

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: I didn't say.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What business are you in?

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: Trucking business.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Trucking business. Trucks run on state roads. If a man in the trucking business had a contract with the state, a big one, that would be pretty good, wouldn't it?  Go on, Jack. Tell him what would happen.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Go on, tell him.

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: You're trying to bribe me, aren't you?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: No, no. No, I'm not trying to bribe you. I'm... I'm only talking things over with you, that's all.

Speaker: hale
Dialogue: You're pretty good at talking. I remember when you first started talking. A place called Upton. You did a lot of talking then and the things you said made sense, to me and a lot of other people. I believed in you... I followed you... and I fought for you. Well, the words are still good. But you're not.  And I don't believe you ever were.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Sugar, follow him. Keep calling in.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Lucy!... Lucy!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'd like Anne to see you now. I'd like Anne to see you now, you drunken sot!  Come on.

Speaker: newsmen
Dialogue: What about the girl's father, Governor? Have you a statement to make?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: All right, all right, gentlemen. I'll give you a statement. This whole thing is a mess of lies. It's a frame. The man that made that statement... have him repeat it to my face. He can't. He vanished. Let me ask you some questions. Where has he gone? Where is he?

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: Maybe you could answer those questions too, Governor.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I won't dignify that question with an answer.

Speaker: another reporter
Dialogue: One more question, Governor... Where's your son?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: At the football stadium, where he's supposed to be. He's going to play for State University, which this administration is responsible for. He's not hiding from anybody, gentlemen. He'll be out there in full view of seventy thousand cheering fans.  One of which will be me. See you, men.

Speaker: crowd voices
Dialogue: Where's Stark? How about Tommy Stark? Hey, Willie, send your boy in.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Why don't they put him in!

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Come on, Willie... send your boy in.

Speaker: drunk
Dialogue: What's the matter, Willie... is your little boy ashamed to show his face?

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Shut up!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Get that man out of here! Come on, get him out of here.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: They're booing you.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Ever since the accident, my head...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: The doctor said it was nothing.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Get dizzy... can't see... dizzy...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You're scared... plain scared.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Get out of here!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Atta boy... get mad. Show some spirit. Jack, tell him what his playing means. Go on, tell him.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You can never tell about a head injury. Maybe the boy's hurt.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: He's hurt? I'm hurt. It wasn't me that wrapped that car around the tree. It wasn't me that got drunk. But me, I'm takin' the rap.  Go on, kid. Get out there and play. Show 'em the kind of stuff a Stark is made of.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I wouldn't know.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Tom... cut it out!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: All right, I'll play. Now get out of here.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Tommy... Tommy... Tommy!

Speaker: sugar boy
Dialogue: B-b-boss, you gotta eat. You g-g- gotta.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'm the one that made him play. I sent him in.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Sit down, Willie. Please sit down.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I sent him in.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: What difference does that make now?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What goes on?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: There isn't a plane flying.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: They gotta fly. This is my son. He's got to live.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: I just got a call from Dr. Birnham. The earliest he can possibly get here will be tomorrow morning.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Isn't there anybody else we can get?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I still think Dr. Stanton should operate.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: That's up to Governor Stark. He wanted another doctor... a specialist. I sent for one.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How bad is it really, doctor?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: He's unconscious... and paralyzed.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Has he got a chance?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: To live? Yes.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Even if the operation's successful -- that is, if he lives -- I think he'll be paralyzed for life.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You'll do everything you can, won't you? Anything between you and me.. that won't count, will it? It doesn't have to. Look, doc, anything you want in the world you just ask for it and you got it. Go on, doc... ask for it.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: There are some things, Governor Stark, that even you can't buy. Do you want me to operate, or don't you?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Yes... I want you to operate.  Please, may I see Tom now?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How much does the doc know?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh, you know what I'm talking about.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: About Anne and me.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He doesn't know a thing... not a thing.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Jack, how is he?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: The boy?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He'll live.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Oh, thank God. How is --

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Willie?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: He blames himself, doesn't he?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He'll find someone else to blame in a few days.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Oh, I tried to call here at the hospital, but I just...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Anne... Anne, why did you do it?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: He wasn't like anybody I ever knew before.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You mean he wasn't like me.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: He wasn't like anybody I ever knew before. I love him, I guess. I guess that's the reason.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Everybody loves him.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: He wants to marry me.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Are you going to?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Not now. It would hurt him. A divorce would hurt his career.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: His career!

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Jack... Jack, what are you going to do? You can't leave him now. He needs you now more than he ever did before.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What Willie needs, Willie's got.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: You don't know him. You've known him all these years and you don't really know him at all.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What about Adam?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Adam?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well, you don't have to worry about him. If Adam finds out it'll be easy to prove a Stanton is no different than anybody else.  Just show him these. Willie was right... a man is conceived in sin and born in corruption. Even Judge Stanton. Show them to him, Anne. Change the picture of the world that Adam has in his head, just like our picture of it has been changed.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Wipe out everything he's ever believed in. It'll be good for him. There's no God but Willie Stark. I'm his prophet and you're his...  Oh, Anne... Anne, I'm sorry. I didn't mean... Anne!

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: What's going on here?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: It's all right, officer... we both work for Willie Stark.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Right over there, that's going to be the main building... fifteen stories high, like on the model. Over there, that's the laboratory. Finest technical equipment in the world.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: What are you trying to convince me of? I've taken the job.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: My reasons are my own. Why are you building a hospital?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: To do some good for the people of the state.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: And get some votes.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh, there are lots of ways to get votes.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Yes, I know... I won't stand for any interference.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I won't interfere. I may fire you, but I won't interfere.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: If that's a threat, you're wasting your time. You know what I think of your administration.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Yes, I know. I'll tell you what... You stay on your side of the fence; I'll stay on mine. Is that a deal?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Now he had us all... me, Anne, and Adam. Now we all worked for him.

Speaker: narrator's voice
Dialogue: And so the eyes of the entire nation are now focused upon Governor Willie Stark, an amazing phenomenon on the American political scene. The whole state is filled with his accomplishments -- each of them, of course, bearing his personal signature, to make sure that no one will ever forget who gave them to the state.

Speaker: narrator's voice
Dialogue: This is the way the roads used to be. But there are those who claim that they were adequate for the people's needs, that you don't need a four- or six-lane highway for a horse and buggy.

Speaker: narrator's voice
Dialogue: When Stark boasts of his great school system, his critics say: you can't go to school and work in the fields at the same time. And they question the benefit of these projects, charging that the need and the poverty of the people is as great as before.

Speaker: narrator's voice
Dialogue: Willie Stark has never forgotten the source of his power: the people who supported him.

Speaker: narrator's voice
Dialogue: He still keeps in touch with these people of the backwoods, making periodic trips to such places as Kanoma City, now famous as his birthplace...

Speaker: narrator's voice
Dialogue: For those who say that Willie Stark is a man of destiny, there are others who claim that he is a man of evil, a man who cares neither for the people nor the state, but only for his own personal power and ambition.

Speaker: narrator's voice
Dialogue: Obviously, these ambitions go far beyond the boundaries of the state. Just how far, only time will tell. Meanwhile, he is here...

Speaker: narrator's voice
Dialogue: ...and from the looks of things, he is here to stay. Willie Stark: messiah or dictator?

Speaker: producer
Dialogue: How do you like it, Governor?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How many theaters will this play in?

Speaker: producer
Dialogue: All over the country.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Hear that, Jack. All over the country.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh, there's one thing in there I didn't like too well. That messiah or dictator.

Speaker: producer
Dialogue: That's our point of view, Governor. And that's the way it stands.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: All right, all right, that's the way it stands... as of now.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Hello, Lucy... How are you making it, Pa?... How are you, Tom?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I made some refreshments for your friends. I'll get them.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: I'll help.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: No, thank you. Thank you kindly.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If you don't mind, Mrs. Stark... the boys have to get back to make the morning editions.  Set 'em up on the porch, fellows. We'll take some pictures out here, first.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Mrs. Stark, please... All right, fellows, take one down there, will you please... Shoot it up this way.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Tom.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Goodbye.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Take care of yourself, Pappy. Oh, uh... how do you like the new radio I got you?  You know how it works? You can get police calls on it. Come here, come here... I'll show you.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: This one for police calls up here.

Speaker: police broadcast
Dialogue: Car sixty-two, proceed to five- eighteen Oak Street. Tom Jones beating his wife again.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: All right, go ahead, go ahead.

Speaker: announcer's voice
Dialogue: We interrupt this program to bring you a special announcement. This afternoon, the body of Richard Hale, father of the girl who died in the automobile accident involving the governor's son, was found. A medical examination revealed he was beaten to death.

Speaker: announcer's voice
Dialogue: The ugly charge of "official murder" has been hurled at the administration by a coalition of Stark's opponents, led by Judge Stanton, lately an outspoken critic of the administration.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Your friend, the Judge.

Speaker: announcer's voice
Dialogue: Thus an almost forgotten incident provided the spark that might set off the explosion needed to rock Willie Stark out of power. The latest report is that impeachment proceedings may be instituted...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How long will it take you to pack? I want you to go back to Capital City with me tonight.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Because I need you.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I'll explain all of that later. Now, Lucy, do like I say.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'll wait outside.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You stay right here, Jack. I want you bear witness to what I've got to say.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: She can be a witness too.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: I'm going back to the capital and get hold of Duffy.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You stay right here, Sadie.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Somebody's got to go back to the capital. I'll go in the other car.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: All right, then tell Duffy not to do anything or say anything until I get there.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Yes, Governor.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Now he needs us. Now that he's in trouble he needs us, so he can lead us around like monkeys with rings in our noses. So he can say to people, look at me, feel sorry for me... just a family man with a wife and a crippled son...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Shut up!

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Willie!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Why don't you leave us alone?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Leave him alone. How many scrapes have I gotten him out of? How many girls?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Willie, stop.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's not him they're after. It's me. How many halfwitted apes do you think I'm going to have to pay to square this one? What do you think this is going to cost me?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: What do you think it cost him?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: A man builds for his son. That's all he builds for.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Willie!  Tom... Tom.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Give me a drink, Jack.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: She'll go.

Speaker: pappy
Dialogue: No good, Willie. No good.

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: Mr. Speaker, I offer a house resolution. Whereas Willie Stark, governor of this state, has been guilty of incompetence, corruption, and favoritism in office -- yes, and other high crimes -- that he is hereby impeached, and ordered to be tried by the senate.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What's the score?

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: They're lined up against you solid. They had a meeting.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How do you know? Were you there?

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Me? What would I be doing there?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Selling me out.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How many votes have we got?

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Eleven.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: We need twenty.

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: We might be able to dig up a few more.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Yeah. Do you know how?

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh, Jack. Come here. What have you got in your black book about that old friend of yours?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Who do you mean?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You know who I'm talking about... your old friend, the Judge.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If and when you need it.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: If and when? I need it right now. He's got four senators wrapped up in his hip pocket. Come on, come on, boy... what have you got?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'm going to give him a break. If he can prove it isn't true, I won't spill it.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I ought to bust you, Jack.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I promised two people I'd do it this way.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Who are they?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Myself... and someone else. It doesn't matter who. I'm going to give him a break.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: All right, give him a break. But if you got the facts, you got the facts. The truth is sufficient... just like it says in the Bible.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: That's the way it's going to be.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: All right, boy... I'll trust you. Where are you going?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'll be around.

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: Who else do you think he promised, Willie?

Speaker: sadie
Dialogue: You'd be smart... play square with him. You're going to need people like us around.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Are you sure?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: The chips were down, and Willie knew it. He was fighting for his life. He roared across the state making one speech after another. And all of them added up to the same thing... "It's not me they're after, it's you!"

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Willie hollered foul. Willie knew if you hollered long enough, hard enough, and loud enough, people begin to believe you. Just in case they didn't, he organized spontaneous demonstrations.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Tell the boys to get the hicks out. Bring 'em in from the sticks, empty the pool halls. Turn 'em out. Turn the yokels out.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: In case anyone hollered back, he organized spontaneous slugging. Willie pulled every trick he ever knew -- and added a few more.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Hey, Sugar!  You'll never live to be impeached!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Boy, I'll live to be President...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I've got fourteen senators to vote against impeachment. If I win, you're out of politics.

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: I'll do whatever the Judge says.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: And always the trail led to one place... Burden's Landing... and the Judge.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You sure you don't want me to go in with you?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'm sure.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Well, hurry it up, boy. We've got places to go.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Judge, I beg you, as a favor to yourself, to me... call up, release your votes.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I made a mistake once, Jack... when I resigned. It was too easy then, just resigning, pulling out. No, Jack, I've made my choice. I have nothing more to lose.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Judge, you know what Stark is capable of. Think it over. I'll leave now. I'll come back tomorrow and we'll talk about it again. You can give me your answer then.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I can't wait until tomorrow. I'm a very impatient man.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I told you not to come in here.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Is it true, Judge, that you're behind the impeachment proceedings?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Yes, it's true.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I wanted to hear you say it with your own silver tongue.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Well, you've heard it. If that's all you came to hear you could have saved yourself a trip.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Mind if I pour myself a drink? How about you, Judge, will you have one? You better... You're going to need it.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What'd he say, Jack?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You'll get your answer tomorrow.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Are you kidding? Did you show it to him, or didn't you?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Show me what?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: That's what I figured. Let's get down to cases, Judge. Do you remember a man with the name of Littlepaugh?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Remember the Fortune Electric Company?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Of course. I was their counsel for over ten years.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Remember how you got the job?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How did you find out?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Do you remember how you got the job?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: You know, Judge, dirt's a funny thing. Some of it rubs off on everybody. How did you get the job, Judge? Blackmail?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I swear I never even remembered his name. Isn't that remarkable, Jack? I never even remembered his name. It's all so long ago it's hard for me to realize it ever happened.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Yeah. But it did.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Yes, it did. But it's difficult for me to realize it.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: For me too, Judge.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Thanks for that much.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Well, I guess you know what the next move is, don't you?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Yes, I do. Jack Burden. Willie Stark's hatchet man.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I asked you... how did you find out?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: This would never stand at law, not for a minute. It happened over twenty- five years ago, and you could never get any testimony. Everybody is dead.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Everybody except you, Judge. You're alive. And people think you're a certain kind of man. And you just couldn't bear for people to think otherwise.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Ever since then I... I've done my duty. I... I'm responsible for many good things.  But I also did this.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Yes, yes, you did.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Judge, I beg of you, call and release your votes, for your sake.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: You have tender sensibilities for a hatchet man.  Good night, gentlemen.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: How about my answer?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: You'll have it in the morning.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I want it tonight.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: In the morning. Good night, gentlemen.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How did you find out?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: We've got a lot to do. It's getting late, Jack. Let's get back to town.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You know we're through, don't you?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Aw, you don't mean that, boy.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's all right, doc. Just here to discuss some politics with the Judge.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Oh, I see.  Well, good night.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Did you give him --

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Wait a minute, Jack --

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Answer me. Did you give --

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Aren't you going back with him?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Why not? You belong with him. Jack, how could you have done it? When Anne brought me those papers she told me you promised not to tell Stark until...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yeah. I know.  Well, I kept my promise.

Speaker: stanton
Dialogue: Anne? Anne?

Speaker: announcer's voice
Dialogue: From all over the state they're streaming in. From the hill country and farms, the lumber camps... by boat, by train, by horse, and on foot. Willie Stark's army.

Speaker: announcer's voice
Dialogue: The state capital is filled with rumors, one of which is that Stark is planning to seize power by force. As commander of the state militia, he has --

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Come in. The door's open.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Jack...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No, I want to see you cry.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Stop it!

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I called you. All afternoon I've been calling you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I know. I was here.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: You've got to tell Adam. You've got to see him.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Tell him what?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: He knows about me and...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: About you and Willie?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I tried to explain to him. I... I tried to explain to him that it wasn't the way he thought it was.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How was it, Anne? You tell me.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: He hit me, Jack. My own brother... he hit me.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Your brother is an old-fashioned man. He believes in his sister's honor. Me, I'm a modern man.  The twentieth-century type. I run.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I'm frightened, Jack.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: For who? Your brother, or Willie?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: We're through.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Who's through with who?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: He called me this afternoon. He's going back to Lucy. He said it was better that way.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Better for who? Him.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Both of us.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Did he tell you that too when he asked you to betray the Judge? At least I walked out on him.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Oh Jack... help me, please, please. Adam's all I've got left now. Oh, Jack, if you ever loved me...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If I ever loved you.  I'll go find Adam.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Where do you think you're going?  Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't recognize you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Do you know who Dr. Stanton is?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Did he try to come through here today?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Haven't seen him, sir.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well, can you check the other entrances?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: If you care to come inside and wait, Mr. Burden, we can find you a seat.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No, thanks. I'll wait out here. If Dr. Stanton shows up, let me know. Pass the word along to the boys, will you?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: loudspeaker
Dialogue: All right now. Everybody... that means everybody... let's let Willie know we're here! All together: WE WANT WILLIE. WE WANT WILLIE.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: We will first proceed to take the judgment of the senate on the question of the impeachment of the governor.

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: Mr. Speaker, this is a farce to ask us to vote in the face of the kind of intimidation and pressure that has been exerted here in the past few weeks. Even that crowd outside, yelling on cue, is part of that pressure.

Speaker: crowd noise
Dialogue: We want Willie. We want Willie.

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: Attention, please. Attention, please. This is a special announcement from Willie Stark to you people out there. He doesn't want any one of you to leave...

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: He wants you to stay in front of this state Capitol until the fight is over. If you want Willie Stark to win, stay where you are.

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: Do you hear me... stay where you are. Don't go away. Stay where you are. Don't go away.

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: Attention, please. Attention, please. The balloting on the impeachment proceedings against Governor Stark has just ended. This is the result: Willie Stark has won.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: They tried to ruin me. But they are ruined. They tried to ruin me because they did not like what I have done. Do you like what I have done?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Remember, it's not I who have won, but you. Your will is my strength, and your need is my justice, and I shall live in your right and your will. And if any man tries to stop me from fulfilling that right and that will, I'll break him. I'll break him with my bare hands. For I have the strength of many.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Hello, Jack boy, I'm glad you're here. I knew you'd come back.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Oh, doctor, I'm very glad to see you.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Stand back, everybody. Stand back.

Speaker: sugar boy
Dialogue: D-does it hurt m-much, boss? D-d- does it hurt much?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Anne, Anne... Where are you going?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I don't know. Leave me alone.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: To do what?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I don't care.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No, that's too easy.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I don't know, I don't know, I don't know.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Leave me alone, please.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No, no more.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: He's dead.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We're alive.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: My brother's dead.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We've got to go on living.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: So that Adam's death has meaning, so that it wasn't wasted. Anne, our life has to give his death meaning. Don't you see that? Look at those people...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Look at them! They still believe in him. And we've got to make them see Willie the way Adam saw him, or there's no meaning in anything... anything.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Mr. Burden... the governor's asking for you. You better hurry. He's going fast.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Will you wait here?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Will you wait here?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It could have been the whole world, Willie Stark. The whole world... Willie Stark. Why did he do it to me... Willie Stark? Why?
